<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q41')" data-correct-answer="D">
<strong style="display: block;">Two firms, Alpha and Beta, are identical in all aspects except for their leverage. Alpha is unlevered with $r_U = 8\%$, while Beta has $D/E = 0.6$ and a cost of debt $r_D = 5\%$. According to Modigliani and Miller Proposition II (no taxes), what is Beta’s cost of equity ($r_E$)?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q41" value="A"> A. 8.5%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q41" value="B"> B. 9.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q41" value="C"> C. 9.5%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q41" value="D"> D. 9.8%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q41" value="E"> E. 10.5%</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q41" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: D.  
Using MM Proposition II (no taxes):  
$r_E = r_U + \frac{D}{E}(r_U - r_D)$.  
Substituting: $r_E = 0.08 + 0.6(0.08 - 0.05) = 0.08 + 0.018 = 0.098 = 9.8\%$.  

Thus, **leverage raises the cost of equity** from 8% to 9.8%, reflecting the higher financial risk faced by shareholders even though the firm’s overall cost of capital ($r_U$) remains unchanged.
</div>
